metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Hindu Undivided Family of Gandalal

facts.text: Hindu undivided family (HUF) of Gandalal and his four sons (Girdharlal, Hansraj, Nandlal, Ramniklal) carried on cloth business in Wadhwan, Kathiawar, outside British India.

In 1944, Nandlal came to Bombay and started cloth business in partnership as Amulakh Amichand Co. Nandlal's share: ten annas; partners from Amulakh Amichand family: six annas. Amulakh family supplied no capital; Nandlal financed alone.
Nandlal received Rs. 50,000 from HUF on April 13, 1944; Rs. 50,000 on April 27, 1944; aggregate Rs. 50,000 on June 8 and 29, 1944 (total Rs. 1,50,000).
Assessee's case: Rs. 1,00,000 gifted to each son by father; June sums were loan to Nandlal; Nandlal partner in individual capacity.
Department's case: Rs. 1,50,000 from HUF utilised as capital in partnership.
Girdharlal joined Bombay firm; allotted five annas share out of Nandlal's ten annas.
Partnership started cloth business at Banaras; partners: Bombay partners + Banaras outsider; third brother joined Banaras firm without capital.
For assessment year 1945-46, ITO held HUF resident in taxable territories (British India), included Rs. 1,50,000 under s. 4(1)(b)(iii) as brought/received in British India.
Appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner dismissed.
Tribunal: Nandlal/Girdharlal represented HUF in firms; money from HUF; but businesses not 'affairs' of HUF; HUF non-resident; delete Rs. 1,50,000; status HUF but non-resident.
Commissioner referred question under s. 66(1): Whether HUF represented by Nandlal in Amulakh Amichand Co., Bombay, resident in taxable territories for 1945-46.
Bombay High Court answered negative, agreeing with Tribunal.
Special leave granted; appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Hindu undivided family of Gandalal represented by Nandlal in the firm of Amulakh Amichand Co. of Bombay was resident in the taxable territories in the year of account relevant for the assessment year 1945-46, under s. 4A(b) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

petitioner_arguments.text: Partnership business in Bombay/Banaras by coparceners representing HUF constitutes 'affairs' of HUF under s. 4A(b); control and management partly in taxable territories, making HUF resident; Rs. 1,50,000 taxable under s. 4(1)(b)(iii).

respondent_arguments.text: Partnership is between individual coparceners and strangers, not HUF; businesses belong to firms/partners under Partnership Act; not 'affairs' of HUF capable of control/management by HUF; HUF's cloth business wholly outside; non-resident.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 4A(b) Indian Income-tax Act, 1922; Indian Partnership Act, 1932; Hindu law

court_reasoning.text: Partnership created by coparcener (Karta or not) is contractual between individual coparcener and strangers; governed by Partnership Act; HUF cannot be partner; control/management of partnership in hands of individual coparcener, not HUF.
court_reasoning.key_observation: HUF exercises no controlling power over partnership firm under Hindu/Partnership law.

court_reasoning.text: 'Affairs' in s. 4A(b) means those capable of being controlled/managed by HUF as such; partnership not such affair; HUF's own business outside taxable territories; no residence via partnership.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Control/management means de facto, not mere right; HUF had no control over Bombay/Banaras firms.

court_reasoning.text: Income from partnership accrues to HUF, but place of accrual and residence differ; residence by seat of control/management of affairs.

Dissent (Hidayatullah J.): Investment/partnership by coparceners using HUF funds is 'affair' of HUF under Hindu law (communion of interest); control/management partly in British India by coparceners managing firms; HUF resident.
court_reasoning.key_observation: View from Hindu law: coparceners' actions benefit family; de facto control in taxable territories.

holdings.text: Partnership business by coparcener with strangers not 'affair' of HUF under s. 4A(b); control/management not by HUF; HUF non-resident in taxable territories for 1945-46; Rs. 1,50,000 not taxable under s. 4(1)(b)(iii).

precedents_cited.case_name: V. V. R. N. M. Subbayya Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Test for HUF residence under s. 4A(b): control/management of affairs wholly outside; 'affairs' relevant to income-tax.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kshetra Mohan Sannyasi Charan Sadhukhan v. Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax, West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Partnership by coparcener is between individual and others, not family.

precedents_cited.case_name: B. R. Naik v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Control/management means de facto control, not mere right/power.

precedents_cited.case_name: Charandas Haridas v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Coparcener joining partnership: view under Partnership law, Hindu law, Income-tax law separately.
Hindu law: no definite share in undivided family; proceeds to common chest.

precedents_cited.case_name: Katama Natchiar v. Rajah of Shivaganga
precedents_cited.relevance: Hindu law: community of interest and unity of possession among coparceners.
Income from partnership by coparcener belongs to HUF.

precedents_cited.case_name: Murugappa Chetty & Sons v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Income from partnership by coparcener belongs to HUF.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kaniram Hazarimull v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Income from partnership by coparcener belongs to HUF.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Residence of HUF: control/management of affairs wholly without taxable territories; remittance taxable if resident; reference to High Court.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Partnership Act, 1932
statutes_cited.relevance: Partnership between coparcener individually and strangers; HUF cannot be partner; control in partners' hands.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court (majority: S.K. Das J. for himself and Kapur J.) dismissed the Commissioner's appeal, upholding Bombay High Court and Tribunal that HUF was non-resident under s. 4A(b); partnership not HUF's 'affair'; Rs. 1,50,000 deleted. Hidayatullah J. dissented.
outcome.relief_granted: Rs. 1,50,000 excluded from assessment; HUF non-resident for 1945-46.

key_quotes.text: The word 'affairs' must mean affairs which are relevant for the purpose of the Income-tax Act and which have some relation to income.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: [W]hen a coparcener carries on business in partnership on behalf of the Hindu undivided family, the affair is of the coparcener and not of the family, but when the business is carried on by the family itself then it is the affair of the family and not of the coparceners.
key_quotes.speaker: high_court
key_quotes.significance: High Court's view upheld by majority.

key_quotes.text: Their investing moneys, becoming partners and running the partnership... were, from the view point of the coparcenary according to Hindu law, as much the affair of the rest of the family as their own.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dissenting view on HUF affairs under Hindu law.
